In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the code for the `timezone_bumper` function in Julia:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int=3)
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date, bump::Int)
    throw(ArgumentError("Function only works for DateTime types, not Date types."))
end
```

With this code snippet, you can pass a DateTime and bump value to the `timezone_bumper` function and it will increase the timestamp by the specified number of hours. If you try to pass a Date value instead of a DateTime value, the function will throw an error as specified.
